text:
Fifth Avenue, east side, from East 46th to 47th Streets, showing the Windsor Hotel occupying this frontage. This structure was disastrously destroyed by fire on St. Patricks Day, March 17, 1899. The 3-story Windsor Arcade stood here from 1899 to 1925.

NEG # 3316

About 1885?

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Fifth Avenue, east side, north from and including 46th Street, showing the Windsor Hotel from 46th to 47th Streets. The 7-Story building on the S.E. corner of 50th Street is the Buckingham Hotel (opened 1876); and beyond it may be seen the trees on the grounds of the Catholic Orphan Asylum, from 51st to 52nd Streets, the block above the Cathedral.

Compare this picture with Fifth Avenue, north from 46th Street, about 1890, which will show the ground floor of the house on the S.E. corner of 46th Street remodeled for business, and the new 8-story Belgravia on the N.E. corner of 49th Street where this picture shows a vacant lot. The spires of St. Patrick's Cathedral, begun in the fall of 1885 and finished three years later, will also rise from behind the Buckingham; in this picture only the preliminary construction work is visible.

The same scene in 1906 will show the Windsor Arcade, which was built after the hotel was destroyed by fire on March 17, 1899.

Late 1885.

Brown Brothers.

A view similar to the item referred to. Note the changes that are mentioned. In addition is the St. Patrick's Cathedral tower construction. This appears to the left.

About 1890.

Thru The New York Historical Society.

Fifth Avenue, east side, north from and including 46th Street, showing the Windsor Hotel from 46th to 47th Streets. The 7-Story building on the S.E. corner of 50th Street is the Buckingham Hotel (opened 1876); and beyond it may be seen the trees on the grounds of the Catholic Orphan Asylum, from 51st to 52nd Streets, the block above the Cathedral.

Compare this picture with Fifth Avenue, north from 46th Street, about 1890, which will show the ground floor of the house on the S.E. corner of 46th Street remodeled for business, and the new 8-story Belgravia on the N.E. corner of 49th Street where this picture shows a vacant lot. The spires of St. Patrick's Cathedral, begun in the fall of 1885 and finished three years later, will also rise from behind the Buckingham; in this picture only the preliminary construction work is visible.

The same scene in 1906 will show the Windsor Arcade, which was built after the hotel was destroyed by fire on March 17, 1899.

Late 1885.

Brown Brothers.

A view similar to the item referred to. Note the changes that are mentioned. In addition is the St. Patrick's Cathedral tower construction. This appears to the left.

About 1890.

Thru The New York Historical Society.

North on Fifth Avenue from south of 46th Street, showing Windsor Hotel.

About 1890.

August Loeffler, Photographer,
from P.L. Sperr, collection.

Fifth Avenue, east side, between 46th and 47th Streets, showing firemen fighting the fire which destroyed the Windsor Hotel.

March 17, 1899.

International News Photos, Inc.

Fifth Avenue at N.E. corner of 46th Street, looking across the ruins of the Windsor Hotel to the 47th Street, from the S.W. corner of 46th Street, after the fire on St. Patrick's Day. More than forty-five bodies were found in the ruins, some of them not until a month after the disaster.

Later pictures of this block show the three-story Windsor Arcade for stores and offices, shortly to be erected, which filled the entire Fifth Avenue side of the block. A part of this will still be standing in 1920 alongside of the eight-story W. &. J. Sloane Building, built between 1910 and 1916, on the S.E. corner of 47th Street. By 1925 it will have given way to the twelve-story S. &. W. Straus Building.

March 18, 1899.

International News Photos, Inc.

Fifth Avenue, intersection 46th and 47th Streets, showing the Windsor Hotel, West side 7 stories high.

Charles L. Hitznann.
N.Y.City. 1900.

Fifth Avenue, east side, from 46th to 47th Streets, showing Windsor Arcade, which replaces Windsor Hotel after the latter burned.

A tall office building now occupies the site.

About 1907.

Wurts Brothers, Photographers.

neg. #613

562 Fifth Avenue at N.W. corner of 46th Street, showing Thorley's a famous florist shop.
About 1919.

NEG. # 4736

2-8 West 46th Street, adjoining and west of the S.W. corner of Fifth Ave. The view shows the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, erected
in 1861.
About 1919.
Charles E, Moore.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

4-16 West 46th Street, south side, west of Fifth Ave. At the left is the Fifth Avenue Baptist Church, 4-8 West 46th Street.
The Church was built in 1861.

About 1922.

Gift of E. M. Jenks.

According to the New York Sun of December 27, 1937, Nos. 12 and 14 will have their upper three floors removed and utilized as 2-story
business structures with store fronts.

560 Fifth Avenue, at S.W. corner of 46th Street.
June 1926.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

West side of Fifth Avenue from 46th to 47th Streets.
August 18, 1929.
P.L. Sperr, Photographer.

Fifth Avenue, west side, north from 46th Street,
1931.
New York Edison Company Collection.

Fifth Avenue (across the center of view, from right to left margins) from 46th (right) to 54th (left) Streets and environs, as viewed from the air, prominently showing the cleared area on the west side of the Avenue where Rockefeller Center (Radio City) will rise. Sixth Avenue is along the lower edge and forms the westerly border of this major building enterprise. The photographer is viewing eastward to show in the center, St. Patrick's Cathedral, Saks Fifth Avenue Department Store, No. 444 Madison Avenue, the new (under construction) Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, and the General Electric (at this date known as the R.C.A) Building. To the right appears the Grand Central Building. The Rockefeller Center demolition has progressed to a point where the only obstacle is the building in the center foreground, east of Sixth Avenue. It is reported to be occupied by an alleged speak-easy and the owner refuses to vacate. Court assistance will aid this situation and excavation will then be started.

August 1, 1931.

International Newsreel Photo.

text:
S.W. Straus & Co., Fifth Avenue at N.E. corner of 46th Street.
1921.

Fifth Avenue, East Side, between 45th and 47th Streets and extending towards Madison Avenue, about 200 feet, showing former location and building of Hotel Windsor.

Ref: King's Handbook of New York.
P.DIS.

Copyright 1894 by J.S. Johnston, New York.

Neg. # 839

Fifth Avenue, east side, north from 46th Street.
White building in centre is Windsor Arcade, on site of Windsor Hotel, which was destroyed by fire.
The Arcade has since been demolished.
1906.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

SLIDE # 15

46th Street, north side, West from and including Fifth Avenue.
August 18, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

2-8 West 46th Street, adjoining and west of the S.W. corner of Fifth Ave. This site was formerly occupied by the Fifth Ave., Baptist Church.
About 1925.
Joseph Smith.

About 1911.
